Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2012 08:51AM cheryl1946 wrote:  The following is the reply that a member of inspire.com got in response to her note to Avon asking just that question. It sounds like Avon is helping.   Cheryl Marc.Hurlbert@avonfoundation.org [Marc.Hurlbert@avonfoundation.org] Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2012 12:49 PM To: Susan  Cc: Eloise.Caggiano@avon.com Hi Sue,  Thank you for your very thoughtful note. Eloise asked me to respond with some detail about where are funds go. I apologize it has taken me a few days to respond.  We agree with you that there is a paucity of resources and support for women with metastatic breast cancer. That is why we keep our eyes open for opportunities and are eager to hear of programs that provides support to metastatic patients. I will provide links to several programs that might be of interest to you. Let me know if you do not see those 'hot spots' and links.  One program we support is through Johns Hopkins University and it is weekend retreats for metastatic patients and their partners or care givers. We are working in 2013 to see how we can roll this model out to other institutions across the country. We have supported Living Beyond Breast Cancer information on metastatic breast cancer and Annual Conference for Women Living with Metastatic Breast Cancer. We were working with Y-Me to launch new and expanded support for women living with metastatic disease. Sadly, the organization Y-Me had to close its doors this past summer. Finally, we have a few programs under consideration for 2013.  On the research front, we fund several research projects to develop new treatments for metastatic disease, understand how a tumor spreads and why it recurs after initial successful treatment, and projects trying to develop new tests to determine what initial cancers are likely to recur. If you type 'metastatic' in our grants database you can find summaries of some of the dozens of research projects.  With regards to your daughters and potential future granddaughters, we also agree with you. We need to understand better what causes breast cancer and prevent it in this first place or give women tips to reduce their risk. Toward this end we have expanded our messaging beyond "get a mammogram" to know your risk and understand what you can do to reduce your risk. The ultimate goal though is to determine the causes and prevent the disease. We fund a "Virus Research Consortium" of 16 scientists working collaboratively and aggressively to determine if a virus might cause breast cancer or one of the subtypes of BC (triple negative BC, inflammatory BC, or other). We are also funding several studies to see if the environment might play a role in breast cancer cause.  I would be happy to talk to you more about the work of Avon Foundation. This short note is just a tip of the iceberg of what we are doing.  Sincerely,  Marc  Marc Hurlbert, Ph.D. Executive Director Avon Foundation Breast Cancer Crusade 777 Third Avenue New York, NY 10017 Tel: 212-282-5560e: Happy Holidays - Our Gift To You M

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 12:46AM cheryl1946 wrote: Can you get a second opinion? Just doesn't seem right to wait that long. Push for a biopsy ASAP. Remember,most lumps are benign. Many years ago I felt a hard lump in my left breast;I thought I felt the same in the right,so ignored it. Fast forward to 2011;had my yearly mammo in April,radiologist said suspicious area seen-see a surgeon. Surgeon saw mammo and examined me 2 days later. said I needed biopsy,but was much more concerned about hard area. That was in April;after 2 MRI's,ultrasound,3 biopsies,PET/cat scan,and a cat scan guided biopsy of shoulder,dx with stage IV metastatic cancer.Not curable,hopefully treatable with hormonals and zometa. I am 65. I had tests and biopsies every week from mid April to end of June,results for all were given to me the same week,except the shoulder bx;done 6/27 results 7/6 because of holiday. Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 04:25PM cheryl1946 wrote: Hey, they are going down, even if it's slow. My ca 27/29 has always been indicative of what is going on. I started out at stage IV, with mets to several bones, and my TM was 135. Started letrozole on July10 2011. TM on 8/20/11 was 53.8. By March 2012 it was 31.7; that's the lowest mine ever got. It started to go up slowly in September 2012; 39.5.  Had a PET/cat scan end of Sept that showed nothing new. Oct 1st TM was 55; onc said scan trumps TM. On 12/4 TM was 140; had another scan that showed more bone mets. Onc says the mets can be too small to see and that's why I had another scan so soon when my TM's started rising. On 12/31 TM was 240. Letrozole discontinued and started monthly faslodex shots 1/8/13. On 2/12 TM 351 and on 3/12 TM 439. Onc says sometimes it takes faslodex 3 months to start working, Just had blood work today and will find out if it's working on Friday. Do you usually have monthly TM's done? Mine were every 2 months until they started going up. Good luck. I hope the letrozole works for a long time. Cheryl

My ca 27/29 has gone from 135 in July to 35.8 in December,and the 2 idc's have shrunk a lot.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 08:53AM cheryl1946 wrote: So if dx with stage IV at the start is rare,then I've been hit with rareness twice. And I resent the hell out of it! In 1995 I got a one in a million disease called transverse myelitis. I walked into ER with severe chest pain and 5 hrs later was paralyzed from T4 to toes. Never worked again (was an RN) and have many residual effects.Walk with a walker,urinary and bowel issues,and a very tight vise-like feeling around my trunk,heavy numbness in right leg,etc. Then last July got stage IV dx with mets to shoulder,back to chest wall,sternum. No surgery,chemo or rads since at stage IV the docs consider it has "seeded" elsewhere and will eventually show up.  I faithfully had mammograms every year,nothing showed. Got dx with MRI.Then PET/cat. Multiple biopsies confirmed dx. Doing okay on letrozole and monthly zometa. CA 27/29 WNL,down from 135.  This July ended up in hospital with atrial fib;heart rate was 140-200 for over 4 hrs. I added 2 more meds to my bunch. Will need heart med the rest of my life. I'm sorry for the rant,I am just so sick of being sick. Thanks for listening.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 12:23PM cheryl1946 wrote: Everyone I know that got on disability (myself included) had already stopped working for various health reasons. It is very important to fill out the paperwork correctly so you don't get denied. You need 40 credits (10 yrs) working under SS. I believe that you have to show that you can't work for at least a year. However,you can work on SS,just have to watch your income so you don't go over your limit. They take the last 10 years of working and use the 3 highest paying years to determine how much your benefit will be. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2012 11:28AM cheryl1946 wrote: My onc ordered liquid morphine for pain. (I am allergic to percocet, percodan, and demerol. Had to pick up the script because that class of drug can't be faxed. So, I called my pharmacy to see if 2 other meds I needed were ready and mentioned that would be filling morphine. They said we don't stock the liquid, only pills. Called oncs nurse back and she said to call around and some pharmacy will have it; they order it all the time. Called local CVS and they said we have 2 strengths; had to call office again to get strength. Nurse said it was 20 mg/5 ml. All the 6 pharmacies I called don't have that strength; none of the pharmacists were aware that it was even made. Called nurse again and told her, she talked to onc and got a script for 100mg/5 ml. 0.5 to 1 ml every 3 hours as needed. That's 10 to 20 mg each dose. Bottle holds 30 ml total. (the size of a plastic med cup they have in hospitals). It come with a syringe that holds from 0.1-1 ml. No refills. All thiese calls took over 2 hours! When my daughter got here with med, found out CVS did not have my insurance info (they said they did), just medicare part D that would not pay any of it, so I paid full price of $24.50 instead of $10 co-pay! I'll be calling insurance on Monday to see if I can be reimbursed. After all that, I took 0.3 ml at first , took some of pain away. At bedtime took 0.4 ml. It helped enough that I could sleep, but I hate that floaty out of it feeling. So I will take it only at night (0.5) and deal with the pain the best I can during the day. Thanks for listening.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2012 12:40PM cheryl1946 wrote: I don't think any ER can turn you away for lack of insurance. The hospital I go to asks if you have insurance and if not gives you a form to fill out for to apply for help. They also work with you to pay co-pays over time. The big problem in not having insurance is how expensive the tests are. That and the fact that they start charging the minute you register at the ER desk. I went to the ER after having bloody urine, had blood drawn and gave urine spec, was in the waiting room for 4 1/2 hrs,saw doc for 5 minutes (he did nothing) and the bill was almost $1,000! Two days later got call from another ER doc who put me on med for uti. (I was furious at the outrageous cost to sit on a hard plastic chair and watch a small tv that had a blue tinged picture.) That said Massachusetts is a state that you MUST have some kind of health insurance. If you don't when you file your income tax, you are penalized. Those that are low income have medicaid,some have only medicare,some have medicare PPO or HMO.

She is doing another PET (if insurance approves it) next week to try and see what's going on. I have had a lot of pain in my left butt that she thinks is sciatica; nothing "lit up" on PET. This pain is an 8 on 1-10 scale. Having pain in both shoulders and in wrist at the base of my left thumb. Will be seeing rheumatologist on Monday for the wrist. She gave me vicodin for the pain, took one and it helps. Also started on stool softener and senna to prevent constipation. I am trying not to worry at this point; if it's more mets, I'll just have to deal with it. Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 12:15PM cheryl1946 wrote: At any given time,you can have a bad reaction to any drug,even one you have taken many times. I had taken amoxicillin many times over the years for various infections. On June 13,2011,I had a sinus infection,got amoxicillin and took one at 4;10pm. By 4:20,I had a pink rash and was itchy. At 4:30,huge hives and face and tongue were swelling. Called 911 and they had a hard time understanding me. My tongue was so big it was outside my mouth. Called my daughter;she went to hospital,called my sister who lives on my street and she came to wait for ambulance with me. Had solu medrol IV in ambulance,that stopped reaction. All I could think was after all the breast cancer crap I will be damned if I die from an allergic reaction. Had epi when I got to hospital,and spent next 6 hrs in ER. Any time you itch or feel "funny' after taking a med,DO NOT take more of it. Okay,I'm getting off my soapbox now.

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2013 08:11AM - edited Mar 21, 2013 08:13AM by cheryl1946 I have had type 2 diabetes for over 20 years.My mother and  her mother both had it. I take many meds for it; metformin, glyburide and 70/30 insulin. Check my blood sugar 2-3 times a day. I can't imagine not testing. raro if your mother has diabetes, you might have gotten it anyway. Other things that may point toward getting diabetes: gestational diabetes, large babies (my twins weighed over 17 lbs and both my daughters and granddaughter had babies over 10 lbs), obesity. Sometimes diet, exercise just don't prevent it. Speaking of diet, watch your carb intake; carbs turn into sugar in the body. Having to take steroids wreaks havoc with blood sugars, but once you stop them, usually things return to normal.I personally feel that if sugars go way up during steroid treatment, you're probably pre-diabetic. Diabetes is very "doable".Just follow docs instructions. Report any extreme thirst and/or hunger, frequent urination, blurred vision, fatigue and irritability, frequent and recurring infections, numbness and tingling in hands and feet. Examine your feet every day to make sure you don't have any skin breakdown. Good luck, Cheryl
